statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Rod Strickland sank his second 3-pointer of the season with 2:07 left to put Miami ahead to stay, and the Heat beat the slumping San Antonio Spurs 88-83 Friday night.
article.headline: Heat send Spurs to sixth loss in eight games
article.linkText: Trend continues: Surging Heat drop sagging Spurs
article.story:
MIAMI (AP) -- The score was tied with just over two minutes remaining when Rod Strickland threw up the kind of shot he hardly ever takes, much less makes. The long jumper went in for his second 3-pointer of the season, helping the Miami Heat beat the slumping San Antonio Spurs 88-83 on Friday night. "The shot clock was winding down," Strickland said. "I just tried to get some room and get a shot up." The basket put the Heat ahead to stay, and they won for the ninth time in 11 games. San Antonio has lost three in a row, and six of eight. The Spurs rallied from an 18-point first-half deficit but missed their final seven shots after taking an 81-78 lead. Strickland's only basket of the second half put Miami ahead 84-81. He had been 1-for-9 from 3-point range this season, with his lone score a 60-footer at the end of the first half against New Jersey. But coach Pat Riley was glad to see Strickland launch a 25-foot try. "I wanted to get something up because we were dying on the shot clock," Riley said. "We needed it." After the Spurs' Terry Porter committed a turnover and Tim Duncan missed a shot, Alonzo Mourning scored for Miami with 45 seconds left to make it 86-81. Duncan sank two free throws, but Porter missed a potential tying 3-pointer with 10 seconds to go. Eddie Jones then made two free throws, giving him 24 points. Duncan had 29 points and 12 rebounds, and teammate Malik Rose scored a season-high 20 points. David Robinson was limited to 22 minutes because of foul trouble and had seven points and seven rebounds. Strickland had 17 points and seven assists. "When Rod is playing like he's playing now, we're a totally different ballclub," Mourning said. Mourning, who missed games Monday and Tuesday because of the flu, had 13 points, five rebounds and four assists in 32 minutes. He fouled out with 43 seconds left. "I was way out of sync," Mourning said. Strickland sank three baskets to help Miami take a 16-2 lead. The margin reached 35-17 early in the second, and 45-27 before the Spurs began to come back. The Heat missed eight consecutive shots, and San Antonio scored the first 11 points of the third. Stephen Jackson's 3-pointer capped the run and gave the Spurs their first lead, 53-51. "We did a great job of turning the game around after going down 18," coach Gregg Popovich said. "We are very close to having a team that is starting to come together." With the score 81-all and 2:49 left, Miami's Brian Grant was called for a flagrant foul, but Antonio Daniels missed two free throws and Porter missed a shot to give the Heat the ball. Strickland then sank his 3-pointer to put them ahead. "We had two free throws and the ball," Robinson said. "That's a chance for four or five points. Those are the things we haven't been taking advantage of lately. It's biting us."

Game notes
A miss by Mourning in the second quarter snapped Miami's streak of 27 consecutive free throws made over a three-game span. ... Duncan scored at least 20 points for the 27th consecutive game. He has a league-leading 36 double-doubles. ... On the road, the Spurs are 13-0 when leading at halftime and 0-8 when trailing.
